December 18, 1994: Fiction
POLITICALLY CORRECT BEDTIME STORIES, by James Finn Garner.
(Macmillan, $8.95.) Classic tales respun to avoid offending current sensibilities.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
WINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $23.95.) A woman pursues her ambition to
become a record-setting aviator in pre-World War II America.
DEBT OF HONOR, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $25.95.) Jack Ryan and C.I.A.
agents vs. a Japanese plot to strike America's territory and economy.
INSOMNIA, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) A widower and a widow, victims of
sleeplessness, behold sinister forces at work in their small Maine town.
THE LOTTERY WINNER, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $22.)
Stories about a couple who win a lottery and devote themselves to solving crimes.
GOD'S OTHER SON, by Don Imus. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A 1981 novel about
Billy Sol Hargus, a lecherous television evangelist from Texas.
DARK RIVERS OF THE HEART, by Dean Koontz. (Knopf, $24.) A man and a
woman, who meet by chance, must flee a powerful Government agency.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$16.95.) A photographer and a farmer's lonely wife in Iowa.
TALTOS, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.) The survivor of a species of witches copes
with his heritage; a sequel to "The Witching Hour" and "Lasher."
NOTHING LASTS FOREVER, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $23.) Three women
doctors in San Francisco contend with lovers, betrayers and killers.
THE GIFT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.) A woman's visit to a small town
changes many lives.
THE CHAMBER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A lawyer represents a
racist who is on death row for his part in a 1967 bombing in Mississippi.
MUTANT MESSAGE DOWN UNDER, by Marlo Morgan. (HarperCollins, $18.) In
Australia's outback, an American woman learns about aboriginal philosophy.
SPENCERVILLE, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $23.95.) A cold war veteran returns
to his Ohio hometown and rescues an old flame from her sadistic husband.
December 18, 1994
Non-Fiction
DON'T STAND TOO CLOSE TO A NAKED MAN, by Tim Allen. (Hyperion,
$19.95.) Anecdotes and meditations on life by the star of "Home Improvement."
CROSSING THE THRESHOLD OF HOPE, by John Paul II. Edited by Vittorio
Messori. (Knopf, $20.) The Pope discusses matters of belief, suffering and hope,
and Christianity's relationship to other faiths.
JAMES HERRIOT'S CAT STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) A
collection of tales by the Yorkshire veterinarian.
COUPLEHOOD, by Paul Reiser. (Bantam, $19.95.) Essays on the ups and downs
of marriage by the television star and stand-up comedian.
BARBARA BUSH: A Memoir, by Barbara Bush. (Drew/Scribners, $25.) The former
First Lady recalls her life, from childhood to the present.
DOLLY, by Dolly Parton. (HarperCollins, $25.) The autobiography of the country
singer.
THE BOOK OF VIRTUES, by William J. Bennett. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Moral
stories adapted from the Greeks, the Bible, folklore and elsewhere.
THE BELL CURVE, by Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray. (Free Press,
$30.) Ways in which differences in intelligence affect American life.
THE HOT ZONE, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $23.) The discovery of a
lethal virus, more infectious than H.I.V., and the efforts to keep it from spreading.
THE WARREN BUFFETT WAY, by Robert G. Hagstrom Jr. (Wiley, $24.95.) An
account of the career of the man said to be the world's most successful investor.
BASEBALL, by Geoffrey C. Ward and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $60.) An illustrated
history of the game.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
NO ORDINARY TIME, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) The
roles of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt during World War II.
IT WASN'T ALWAYS EASY, BUT I SURE HAD FUN, by Lewis Grizzard. (Random
House, $20.) A collection of essays by the late Southern humorist.
ALL THE TROUBLE IN THE WORLD, by P.J. O'Rourke. (Atlantic Monthly, $22.) A
humorist considers problems like overpopulation, famine and plague.
